critique: This document approves a "Code of Fair Competition" for the Paper Stationery and Tablet Manufacturing Industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933. This act was a key component of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, which aimed to address the Great Depression through government intervention in the economy. The document itself doesn't directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security, or social inclusion. However, its core purpose relates to economic regulation. The approval of the code signifies a move towards government intervention in the market to establish fair competition, which aligns with a liberal approach to economic policy during that era. Therefore, the ideological tilt leans liberal. The document doesn't seem to touch upon any social issues, so it is neutral on social inclusion. It also doesn't expand executive power beyond what was already granted by the NIRA. It is neutral on federalism as well. It is also neutral on national security vs civil liberties. It is also neutral on immigration. The document is an example of government intervention in the economy, so it is interventionist.
